instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.D7012: What is D7012? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year model macbook airs, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no pp3v42
threads.message:
Hi there! i feel silly for posting this but i'm a little rusty it seems. This should be a fairly basic issue but here we are
No green light, no PP3v42, no short on PP3v42. I know Pp3v42 is required to enable green light, so the main DC in connection must be the issue? there was liquid damge around <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> and a little in some random spots/ Have replaced ISL and <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>. obviously tested with known working DC board and cable but no change

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no pp3v42
threads.message:
May have an input leakage issue; did you test with fake charger, or lab PSU?
Did you check diode mode to ground at PPBUS/<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>?
<SIGNAL>DCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no pp3v42
threads.message:
My Lab PSU is currently waiting for a fuse since i blew it up so I can't right now :( 

PPBUS diode to ground is 0.712

Pp3v42 diode is 0.3

<SIGNAL>DCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is only 1.7V, that's too low right?
<SIGNAL>DCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> diode is 0.13

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light, no pp3v42
threads.message:
As I suspected, leakage input problem.
Original charger detects it and gets blocked.

Check R/<DIODE>D7012</DIODE> first; if both good, change <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>.

"PPBUS diode to ground is 0.712"
Not sure how did you test it; should be 0.120-0.160 aprox...
